text: - Hi, my name is Ron Wedel.

Thanks for coming here, Mitch.
- Thank you, Ron.

- So today we're gonna be
talking about migrations
from on-premises into native services.
And really in those migrations,
a lot of times the day two operations

becomes front of mind for
a lot of our customers,
from the complexity and the concern
of how to operate in the cloud

from traditionally managing
on-premises workloads.
So Mitch, really what I'd like to ask you

is how can we help build
confidence in our customers
in their day two operations?
A lot of the times they're presented
with this breadth and depth of solutions
and they don't know where to start.
What do you recommend?
- Well, I recommend starting here.
I know there's a lot of breadth
and depth across the AWS service library,

but it's important as you're
building that business case

for why to migrate to
the cloud and why AWS,

to start looking at what's
the art of the possible.

But, you know something,
in true Amazonian fashion,
we need to invent and simplify.

So if you wouldn't mind,
Ron, let's get rid of this.
And for this talk today,

let's focus on how we can
take all of what we just saw
and make it work for you.

So you spend more time innovating

It's easy to say invent and simplify,

or a way to really visualize

how MontyCloud approaches
the simplification
of day two operations?

- Yeah, and with that,
let's pull up a flywheel
because ultimately we wanna make sure

that customers are spending
more time modernizing
than operating and optimizing.

And that's where our integrations
with AWS are gonna help

get rid of that
undifferentiated heavy lifting

so customers can focus on what

And when we look at starting
this flywheel, you know,

modernization could be starting
with a migration to AWS

kicking off this flywheel.

case I wanted to bring up

is customers have started

and they took that first

So if we go from your flywheel
over from modernize to operate,

let's talk about what
operate means to MontyCloud.
Can you gimme a little context on that?

- Yeah, so for us at
MontyCloud, it means that

we're going to deploy a
cloud formation template
into a customer's account.

And all that's doing is
setting up an IAM role.

And with that role,
we're able to help build
a cloud center of excellence for customers
in about 10 to 15 minutes.
And in that time, what's really important
is that we start putting the cloud
into a customer's business context.
And once we have that business context,

it gets a lot easier to
start doing cloud operations.
- Great.
So talk to me about what business context
actually means to MontyCloud.
Does that relate to the technology
or is that just a way to organize
what the technology means to the business?

- It would be the latter.
- Okay.
- Because we want it to be flexible.

Customers aren't thinking
of their business
as AWS accounts or VPCs,
when in reality it is a combination
of AWS accounts, VPCs, shared workloads.

So for us to be able to meet
customers where they are

and allow them to organize
their AWS footprint

into the applications
that power their business,
that's what we wanna start with.
- Great.
I imagine when you put things
in the context of the business,
that also helps with operating things,
especially for highly regulated customers,

say finance or healthcare or
a variety of other industries
that do come with compliance requirements.
Does that help with that story as well?
- Yes, it does because if we think

of the different
configuration best practices

that heavily regulated
customers need to follow,

it makes it a lot easier to
focus on what needs to be done
to meet those compliance frameworks.

So as we look at that,
it could be, you know,

maintaining a certain
patch schedule on servers.

It could be making sure
that resource configurations
aren't open to the public.
Things are encrypted.
Those are the ways that
we're able to really help them there.
And when we look at this business context,
everything has a cost.
- Sure.

- And to be able to say
to this application owner,
"These are the resources,"
give them access to that in a safe way

and show them their

it makes it a lot easier to

- Yes, we are.
'Cause as we look at cloud operations,
we wanna make sure that our customers

have an always-on senior
solutions architect.
Because to be able to go ask,

"Hey, which of my resources
are not compliant?
Which resources am I overspending on?
Why did my bill go up last month?"

This is value we can bring
to customers immediately.
And quite frankly, we don't need them

of services to troubleshoot
when they can take action immediately.

to be opportunities

it doesn't take away from

Your solution will pick
